Articles
Photo Tech EDU Dayhttp://www.dicklyon.com/phototech/
enHTML
Photo Tech EDU Day 1: Photo Technology Overviewhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4PaX8FiNs0
enFlash Video1010Richard Lyon2007117A very fast presentation of optics, camera settings (shutter speed, aperture, and focus), depth of field, tone reproduction…
PhotoTechEDU Day 2: Photo Technology Overview Continuedhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaE7EanXAhA
enFlash Video5523Richard Lyon2007124… SLR, human eye, color spaces, history of color photography…
PhotoTechEDU Day 3: Ray Tracing, Lenses, and Mirrorshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZTLrh2hodmM
enFlash Video5731Rom Clement2007131A presentation of the optics of concave/convex lenses/mirrors. Given the fact that he Clement is stammering and the duration of the presentation (just one hour), I doubt people who have never seen optics before can fully understand this.
PhotoTechEDU Day 4: Contrast, MTF, Flare, and Noisehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tNvFsOvVkOg
enFlash Video5952Iain McClatchie2007214First, the speaker describes luminosity and the Modulation Transfer Function. Then, it speaks about flare, its causes (reflections on the lenses, sensor, and IR cut filter) and the coated lenses.
PhotoTechEDU Day 5: Silicon Image Sensorshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5wQxswwcudg
enFlash Video1019Richard Lyon2007221A presentation of the physics of CMOS and CCD, then some details about anti-aliasing.
PhotoTechEDU Day 6: Digital Camera Image Processing Pipelineshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8ZTVal7ofZ8
enFlash Video5755Richard Lyon2007228A description of the processing done from the data retrieved from the sensor to the generated photography: amplification, analog-to-digital conversion, dark-level adjustment, white-point estimation, demosaicing, noise reduction…
PhotoTechEDU Day 7: Lossy Image Compressionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e3AjmGv5tJ4
enFlash Video5755Ashok Popat200737This presentation dives too much in the maths of compression to be understandable by common people…
PhotoTechEDU Day 8: Diffraction and Interference in Imaginghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vG3h_YoN694
enFlash Video5445Rom Clement2007314After a quick reminder of the diffraction effect (Young experiment), Rom lists some criteria of resolving power. In the second half of the presentation, he speaks about reflective and transmissive gratings.
PhotoTechEDU Day 9: Amateur Astrophotographyhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7vf50StbXG8
enFlash Video1251Ben Lutch2007321An interesting presentation of the challenges of astrophotography: compensating for earth rotation, atmosphere distortion, frame calibration… At the end, someone from Google present an alpha version of a Web service able to find out the location of a given astronomical picture.
PhotoTechEDU Day 10: Image Compression Part 2http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhUjZhsKkzI
enFlash Video5748Ashok Popat2007328This is the continuation of day 7: wavelets, vector quantization, lossless compression…
PhotoTechEDU Day 11: Document Image Analysis with Leptonicahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pCZtGRUa_7s
enFlash Video5537Dan Bloomberg200744After a very unclear (because there is no image or drawing!) introduction to image analysis operations (dilatation, erosion, seedfill), Dam gives some examples of their applications using Leptonicahttp://www.leptonica.org
enHTML.
PhotoTechEDU Day 12: High Dynamic Range Image Capturehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q4GACCvUe9c
enFlash Video1024Greg Ward2007411After some explanation about how to generate a HDR photo (estimating the response function and performing image registration), Greg performs a demo of Photospherehttp://www.anyhere.com
enHTML, speaks about JPEG-HDR, and describes how cameras could directly generate HDR images.
PhotoTechEDU Day 14: Exposing Digital Forgeries from Inconsistencies in Lightinghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lv95oQEkZ0w
enFlash Video1035Hany Farid2007425After explaining that digital image manipulation is very widespread, Hany describes some techniques to detect them and, then, he details two algorithms estimating the location of the light source.
PhotoTechEDU Day 16: Multi-viewpoint Mosaicshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6eD7NfuKYr0
enFlash Video5418Lihi Zelnik200752In the first part of her presentation, Lihi explains how to compute projections to create a flat panorama from several pictures and, in particular, how to correct some distortions of elements of interest. In the second half, she describes how to "artfully" join the pictures together without trying to respect geometry.
PhotoTechEDU Day 18: Non-destructive, Selective, Editing of Photographshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UDCMuKBWZa4
enFlash Video568Uwe SteinmuellerFabio Riccardi2007516A presentation of LightZonehttp://lightzoneproject.org
enHTML, a non-destructive photo editor using operation layers.
Photographic Technology EDU Day 19: Non-destructive, Selective, Editing of Photographshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TEhfrY3iNVU
enFlash Video5728Uwe Steinmueller2007530A good overview of inkjet printing: dye/pigmented inks, thermal/piezo heads, paper types, color space management…
Photographic Technology EDU Day 21: Visualization Via Matlabhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Mykfb8mMBE
enFlash Video5255Richard Lyon2007713Richard gives some information on parsing ICC Color Profiles, ray tracing computation, and diffraction simulation.
PhotoTechEDU Day 22: Measuring, Interpreting and Correcting Optical Aberrationshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agXH4n4SOyE
enFlash Video5826Erik Gross2007620Erik Gross explains how to measure eye aberrations, what are the visual effects of theses and how to cure them with a laser.
PhotoTechEDU Day23: Raw Files and Formatshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLw0A-Y8rQk
enFlash Video152David Cardinal2007827David Cardinal describes the content of raw files and how to use them. He also warns about the fact that we may not be able to read these files in 100 years because we will have not maintain the knowledge of all their dirty tricks.
PhotoGraphic Technology Day 24: Quantization, image texture, and superresolutionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j8UG3LJee8U
enFlash Video4334Lance WilliamsDiego Rother2007827First, Lence Williams explains that interpolating midpoints of the quantization levels is not the best way to reconstruct the signal, its is better to use constraint optimization. Diego Rother then discusses about texture synthesis. I am not sure to understand the link between both.
PhotoTechEDU Day 25: Open-source-based high-resolution camerashttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HjvF4uCRljo
enFlash Video4329Andrey Filippov2007810The founder of Elphelhttp://www.elphel.com
enHTML company describes how he created high-resolution and high speed cameras based on open source (e.g. Linux).
Photographic Tech EDU Day 26: Image quality testing and real-world challengeshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uRtnFIbFO9k
enFlash Video5534Norman Koren2007815The founder of Imatesthttp://www.imatest.com
enHTML lists the quality tests which are part of his software: sharpness, chromatic aberration, noise, lens flare…
PhotoTechEDU Day27: Focus on Resolutionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fi9mnJILIwU
enFlash Video466Ken Turkowski2007822Some thinking about resolution: the 70% rule for Bayer pattern, panoramic resolution…
PhotoTechEDU Day 28: "Capturing more Light": Pragmatic use of HDR Capture and Tonemappginghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4qsoXKVF0dw
enFlash Video1517Uwe Steinmueller200795Uwe reminds the issue of dynamics both for capture and for the support (screen or paper). Then he speaks about the problems to capture HDR shoots (camera motion, objet motion…). He finishes by proposing his "exposure mix & match" methodology.
PhotoTechEDU Day 29: Photographing VR Panoramashttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1_6vO1vBkpc
enFlash Video11342Scott Highton20071017Highton gives a good overview of the current technologies available to shoot panoramas (hardware and stitching software), shows some of his results, describes how he shot them, and gives some advice to get good results.
PhotoTechEDU Day 30: Imaging optics for the next decadehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6VTrb2gl-14
enFlash Video5448Robert E. Fischer2007117Some good information, but Fisher tries to present too much stuff.
PhotoTechEDU Day 31 - Color Balance: Babies, Rugs & Sunsetshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NWVDwpCYg3A
enFlash Video5912Paul Hubel20071212Some algorithms for color balancing, from the gray world to advanced computations able to handle dusk scenes.
PhotoTechEDU Day 32 - Art, Science and Reality of High Dynamic Range (HDR) Imageshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ALfiTDYLtAQ
enFlash Video1511John McCann2008125After speaking about the glare issue, John McCann gives some historical data about high dynamic range in painting, analog photography, and digital photography. He finishes by showing the efficiency of the Retinex algorithm on several examples.
Computation
Modeling the world
Blaise Aguera y Arcas: Photosynth demohttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s-DqZ8jAmv0
enFlash Video927Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos Photosynthhttp://www.ted.com/talks/blaise_aguera_y_arcas_demos_photosynth.html
enFlash Video733Blaise Aguera y Arcas20073A demo of Seadragon and Photosynth.
Learning 3D Models from a Single Still Imagehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bWbEsDbfayc
enFlash Video1838Ashutosh Saxena2008129Ashutosh Saxena describes the algorithms he is using to build a depth map from a single image: his results are rather impressive.
Multi-view Superpixel Stereo in Man-made environmentshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFNDX1BWlxo
enFlash Video1655Branislav MicusikJana Kosecka200847A detailed description of an algorithm building a 3D model from a small set of photos taken from known positions.
Finding Paths Through the World's Photoshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLLzV5qeKyk
enFlash Video655Noah SnavelyRahul GargSteven M. SeitzRichard Szeliski200881A demo of Microsoft's Photosynth.
Viewfinder: How to Seamlessly "Flickrize" Google Earth / A Collaboration between the Institute for Creative Technology and the Interactive Media Division of the School of Cinematic Arts, USChttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LRAj21y23r8
enFlash Video5830Michael Naimark2008414How to find the pose of a photo in a 3D model, such as Google Earth. The tools seem rather simple to implement, but the aim here is probably more to act as a brain teaser to get some community momentum in this domain, rather than performing a technological prowess.
IM2GPS: estimating geographic information from a single imagehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgif39IKT9A
enFlash Video4726James Hays200885Using the same type of algorithm than in the previous talk, James Hays tries to locate a picture by digging through 6.000.000 geotagged photos.
PhotoSketch: A Google SketchUp Plugin for Photo-Centric 3D Modelinghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PIdJRS-Hivw
enFlash Video5935George Wolberg2009624A demo and technical presentation of a Google SketchUp plugin able to greatly simplify the 3D modelling by automatically rebuilding the geometry of the scene and the camera poses.
Google Street View: Capturing the World at Street Levelhttp://www.australianscience.com.au/research/google/36899.pdf
enPDFDragomir AnguelovCarole DulongDaniel FilipChristian FruehStéphane LafonRichard LyonAbhijit OgaleLuc VincentJosh Weaver20106A description of the evolution of Google Street View technology (captors and algorithms).
Reconstructing Romehttp://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=5481934
enHTMLSameer AgarwalYasutaka FurukawaNoah SnavelyBrian CurlessSteven M. SeitzRichard Szeliski20106Reconstructing a 3D model from thousands of Flickr images.
The Distributed Camera: Modeling the World from Online Photoshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=opRZUMrLJOM
enFlash Video12132Noah Snavely2012725The continuation of the previous work: after building a model from thousand of photos, they experiment on how to build momentum for intentional photo gathering, and they start to study how to find out where and when a picture was taken.
Using Data to "Brute Force" Hard Problems in Vision and Graphicshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpp0BwatG90
enFlash Video5434Alyosha Efros2007813Alyosha Efros explains how to dig in millions of photos to find something to fill a hole in a given photo, to evaluate the size of some objects, to evaluate the 3D geometry of the scene…
Scene Discovery by Matrix Factorizationhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OLV1IIpTPow
enFlash Video5455Ali Farhadi2008324Using matrix computation to detect correlations in photo labels.
What Do Those Images Have In Common?http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YoOULXBa2wg
enFlash Video5953Sinisa Todorovic2008325Using region segmentation, graph recording region embeddings, and graph matching to automatically (i.e. with no human-provided input) detect objects common in a small set of photos.
Radioactive astronauts: images worth a thousand experimentshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2dwkZ8-PDE
enFlash Video4357Sylvain Costes2008422The analysis of a huge 4D dataset to evaluate how cosmic particles damage DNA.
Large image databases and small codes for object recognitionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bakKQFEFLCA
enFlash Video1113Rob Fergus2008515Rob Fergus describes an algorithm to find the nearest neighbours and, then, perform recognition on a very large set of images.
The LabelMe dataset and its applications to scene and object recognitionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OPPFBaKc2eU
enFlash Video1411Bill Freeman2008815There are three parts in this talk:
1) creating virtual landscape by rotating , translating or going forward into fused matching images
2) a presentation of the LabelMe dataset
3) object recognition by using scene recognition.
A General Approach to Discovering, Registering, and Extracting Features from Raster Mapshttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7qXLEopuKGk
enFlash Video1010Craig Knoblock2010825A rather detailed description of the algorithms used to recognize rasterized maps, to extract the roads and names, and, then, to register these maps.
Photographs
The Ansel Adams Zone System: HDR Capture and Range Compression by Chemical Processinghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Xanb3J81EA
enFlash Video5923John McCann2010121John McCann describes the manipulations (dodging and burning) performed by Ansel Adams in order to fit a high dynamic range on a printed paper.
Hobbyist to Flickr Celeb: Building a Career with Social Networking (Kevin Meredith aka lomokev)http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sWXhlxq1_iw
enFlash Video5444Kevin Meredith2010811Kevin Meredith (a Lomo fan) explains how he got into photography and how he became popular on Flickr.
Hardware
FullView Panoramic Camerashttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fO3ZfDg6aaU
enFlash Video4029Vic Nalwa2009527A description of FullView's technology and a comparison to other panoramic camera designs.
Lytro unveils radical new camera designhttp://news.cnet.com/8301-30685_3-20122734-264/lytro-unveils-radical-new-camera-design/
enHTML20111019Lytro created a new kind of camera which records the rays of light instead of the image they generate on a plane.
Canon PowerShot G1 Xhttp://www.canonrumors.com/reviews/canon-powershot-g1-x/
enHTML201226Canon Rumors' initial PowerShot G1 X review.
Les meilleurs appareils photo 2012 selon TIPAhttp://www.zone-numerique.com/news-12807-les-meilleurs-appareils-photo-2012-selon-tipa.html
frHTML201254The title says all.
Canon announces EOS Rebel T4i, we go hands-on with first touchscreen DSLRCanon has just announced their latest Rebel-series DSLR, the T4i. The new flagship Rebel combines a new sensor, Digic 5 processor, and 3-inch touchscreen LCD in a compact SLR package.http://cameras.reviewed.com/news/canon-announces-eos-rebel-t4i-we-go-hands-on-with-first-touchscreen-dslr-2
enHTMLTJ Donegan201268First impressions of Canon new DLSR.
First Review: Canon EF 600 f/4L IS IIhttp://camerarumors.blogspot.fr/2012/06/first-review-canon-ef-600-f4l-is-ii.html
enHTMLCraig Blair2012612The title says all.
Canon EOS 70D reviewCanon's most enthusiast-friendly APS-C SLR to datehttp://www.techradar.com/reviews/cameras-and-camcorders/cameras/digital-slrs-hybrids/canon-eos-70d-1162746/review
enHTMLAngela Nicholson201372Some information on the 70D and a little feedback after having used a pre-production camera.
Dual Pixel CMOS AF -- The story of "Technology" and "Passion"Interviews with Developershttp://www.learn.usa.canon.com/app/pdfs/articles/Canon_Developers_Interview_nonfacing_pressquality.pdf
enPDFHiroshi MiyanariKoichi FukudaKazuo NakagawaTakeshi SakaguchiYutaka IshidaHiroshi Matsushima2013712These pseudo interviews are marketing advertisement with no real technical information.
Nikon D7200 : Test complethttp://www.lesnumeriques.com/appareil-photo-numerique/nikon-d7200-p24717/test.html
frHTMLBruno Labarbere2015414A test of the D7200.
Nikon D7200 Review http://www.dpreview.com/reviews/nikon-d7200
enHTMLJeff KellerRichard Butler20156Another one.
Adobe taps the power of negative thinkinghttp://www.news.com/Adobe-taps-the-power-of-negative-thinking/2100-1041_3-6136875.html
enHTML20061120Adobe tries to establish a standard for raw pictures.
dove evolutionhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYhCn0jf46U
enFlash Video1020061014Photo retouching for a Dove commercial.
extreme photo retouchinghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P4wI_o8gyxA
enFlash Video22820061023The title says all.
David Griffin: How photography connects ushttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4eye-hqQqQ
enFlash Video174David Griffin: How photography connects ushttp://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/david_griffin_on_how_photography_connects.html
enFlash Video1457David Griffin20082The stories of some National Geographic photos.
Imaging the Antikythera Mechanismhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rxNg-tXPPWc
enFlash Video102Tom Malzbender201035Some examples of using Polynomial Texture Mapping to analyze objects. A spectacular example is the Antikythera Mechanism, an astronomical mechanical computer. But the most stunning is the fact that Greeks have been able to build this mechanism 200 BC.
Erik Johansson: Impossible photographyhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mc0vhSseGk4
enFlash Video622Erik Johansson: Impossible photographyhttp://www.ted.com/talks/erik_johansson_impossible_photography.html
enFlash Video622Erik Johansson201111The composite photos are quite good, this is a pity that Erik Johansson is not a good speaker.
Linear Book Scannerhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4JuoOaL11bw
enFlash Video3041Dany Qumsiyeh201253A detailed description of a low cost book scanner.
For true panoramic images, toss this camera in the air. SeriouslyThe ball-shaped Panono contains 36 2-megapixel lenses and takes a 360x360-degree image when it is thrown into the air.http://news.cnet.com/8301-11386_3-57611859-76/for-true-panoramic-images-toss-this-camera-in-the-air-seriously/
enHTML20131112A camera that you can throw in the air to shot a full panorama.
